Here is my 2 cents on Doctrine (ORM)

Posted by Nurul Ferdous on Sep 25, 2010 in Code Igniter, Featured, MySQL, PHP, Symfony, Zend Framework | 0 comments

What is Doctrine?
Doctrine is a popular ORM for PHP which works with RDBMS via PHP objects. This is built inspired by Hibernate from JAVA. This acts as an abstraction layer between PHP and RDBMS.

What is it good for?

  • It really hide the the business logics (tables, sql, relations) via the db abstraction layer while active record map objects to tables.
  • It has a strong caching (of cached caching) system with apc, memcached, sqlite
  • Caching could be activated globally or per query basis
  • Automatic CRUD
  • NestedSet behavior algorithm could be implemented (version 1.x only)
  • pre* and post* method hooks
  • Can work on PHP, YML, Annotations and XML schema files
  • Automatically modify DQL queries
  • Primitive and more complex data type validation
  • Minimize overheads by loading properties only when it’s required
  • DQL supports lot’s of standard SQL features
  • Migration helps making schema versionable
  • Unit Testing has been added recently
  • Anything left? (shoot me a comment I will add it)

What is it not good for?

  • It works on PDO which has lots of open bugs while dealing with PostgreSQL and Oracle
  • Foreign keys cannot be used as identifier
  • Really wants the id columns of all models and some times (not always) magically adds them to the query
  • Due to hydration complex queries may need to be written in a specific order
  • Not all DB functions recognized in DQL
  • Not all data types are supported in DBAL
  • DBAL tries to work on all schemas in a postgresql database
  • Some SQL constructs not supported in DQL
  • Significant OO overhead when not monitoring the generated queries

Describe a scenario where you most definitely wouldn’t use Doctrine?

Though I used it in my last postgresql project where I had to fix them by some jail break. want some example? ok…

  • Gimme a bigserial column via doctrine entity.
  • Deal multiple schema via ORM in same postgresql database and multiple database. if I have to run it via $conn->executeQuery($sql); then why Doctrine?
  • Hard to work with SQLlogger (it shows the query in ui). it should be in FirePHP. I am writing a wrapper for that.
  • It sucks (sometimes) while dealing with other than MySQL stuffs

So if it’s a psql based project with multiple db and multiple schemas in same db with more than 5 billions record I won’t go for doctrine.

else I will love to use doctrine. I am a big fan of Hibernate and GORM and Doctrine as well
